resources.string: Long press on pointer to reposition

Koi carp ( Cyprinus carpio ) were selectively bred from wild stock in Asia and Europe and were introduced to New Zealand as ornamental pond fish in the 1960s. In the lower Waikato and Auckland region, koi carp inhabit lakes, wetlands, streams, drains and rivers. Small populations have been found in other locations around the North Island, but so far they have not established in the South Island.

 In New Zealand, they can grow to 70 cm long and weigh up to 14 kg. Males live to about 8 years and females to around 12 years. Koi carp spawn in shallow river and lake margins. A female koi carp is capable of multiple spawnings per year producing on average 100,000 eggs per kilogram of body weight.

 Juvenile koi carp are zooplanktivores, thus inhabit water with poor trophic status. The adults are omnivores that eat invertebrates, plants, fish eggs and small fish. They suck up sediment with their extensible mouths, extract what they eat and expel the remains. This leads to increased suspended sediment in the water column reducing water clarity, submerged aquatic plants, and habitat for zooplankton and small fish.
